Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 44472-012 
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
Federated States of Micronesia: Strengthening the 
Energy Sector Regulatory Framework

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency of the Federated States of Micronesia is the United States dollar. 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  EU  –  European Union 
  FSM  –  Federated States of Micronesia 
  NEP  –  National Energy Policy 
  PUC  –  Pohnpei Utilities Corporation 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  YSPSC  –  Yap State Public Service Corporation 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Policy and advisory technical assistance (PATA) 
Targeting  –  General intervention 
classification 
Sector (subsector)  –  Energy (energy sector development) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling

Location (impact)  –  Rural (low), national (medium), urban (high) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  X. Yao, Pacific Department (PARD) 
Director  R. Guild, Transport, Energy and Natural Resources Division, PARD 
   
Team leader  M. Tonizzo, Young Professional, PARD 
Team members  A. Maxwell, Senior Energy Specialist, PARD 
  A. Woodruff, Urban Development Specialist, PARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In 2012, the Government of the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) approved the 
National  Energy  Policy  (NEP)  after  4  years  of  development  supported  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and the European Union (EU). The goal of the NEP is to “improve the 
life  and  livelihood  of  all  FSM  citizens  with  affordable,  reliable  and  environmentally  sound 
energy.”1 The NEP aims to reduce dependence on imported fuel by increasing generation from 
renewable energy sources and reducing consumption through more efficient energy use. The 
policy set a target of producing 30% of electricity from renewable energy sources by 2020. 
 
2.  Following approval of the  NEP, the government asked for ADB support to develop 
renewable energy generation and increase distribution efficiency in Pohnpei State and Yap 
State.  ADB  responded  to  the  government’s  request  by  supporting  the  preparation  of  two 
proposed projects. In Yap State, ADB’s proposed assistance is expected to replace diesel 
generation with solar and wind generation. In Pohnpei State, ADB’s proposed assistance is 
expected to increase the efficiency of diesel generation and the distribution network.  
 
3.  The technical assistance (TA) is intended to strengthen the energy sector regulatory 
framework to create a better enabling environment for long-term investments in renewable 
energy.2 The TA was developed in consultation with a wide range of stakeholders, including 
national- and state-level representatives. The government concurs with the impact, outcome, 
outputs, implementation arrangements, cost financing arrangements, and terms of reference. 
State-level representatives are informed of the proposed TA and welcome state-specific support. 
The design and monitoring framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Background 
4.  The FSM has a population of 102,800 living on 533 islands that are administered by the 
four autonomous states of Chuuk, Kosrae, Pohnpei, and Yap. During 2006–2008, the FSM 
experienced  negative  growth  that  reached  –2.3%  in  2008.  Starting  from  2009,  the  FSM 
economy showed signs of recovery with real growth of 0.4% in 2009 and 3.1% in 2010.3  
 
5.    The economy is particularly vulnerable to fuel price volatility. Oil imports averaged 10.7% 
of  gross  domestic  product  during  2005–2009.  In  2008,  when  international  crude  oil  price 
reached nearly $150 per barrel, oil imports peaked at 14% of gross domestic product, and 
shrank by almost half in the following year. High fuel prices also have a large impact on the 
energy  sector  as they  translate  into  high  electricity  prices for  end  users. This  is  because 
electricity generation for the main grids in the four states is almost completely based on fossil 
fuel. 
 
6.  Generation, transmission,  and  distribution  are the  responsibility  of four  corporatized 
utilities, one for each state. Each state owns the utility and exercises ownership rights through 
one or more representatives on the utility’s board. Each utility has developed its own tariff 
scheme, but they follow a similar procedure to revise tariffs. The board has the power to 
                                                
1 Federated States of Micronesia. 2010. National Energy Policy. Volume 1.  
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 21 November 2012. 
3 International Monetary Fund estimates.

2 
 
 
approve and adjust tariffs as proposed by the utility’s management upon the presentation of a 
tariff increase proposal. Currently, tariffs cover operating and basic maintenance costs, but at 
different levels in each state, and include a fuel price pass-through. None of the utilities is able 
to  generate  enough  revenue  to  support  large-scale  infrastructure  rehabilitation  or  new 
investments in renewable energy.  
 
B.  Key Development Challenges  
7.  Financing renewable energy investments. Given the high dependence on fossil fuel, 
the NEP identifies renewable energy as the most desirable option for improving energy services. 
Although the NEP set a target of 30% of generation through renewables by 2020, none of the 
utilities  has  developed  an  asset  management  and  financing  plan  for  the  development  of 
renewable generation. The four utilities are currently expanding renewable generation capacity 
solely through external assistance. The EU and the Government of Japan are installing grid-
connected solar photovoltaic panels in Chuuk State and stand-alone systems in the Yap outer 
islands. The EU is also supporting the rehabilitation of the Nanpil hydropower plant in Pohnpei 
State.  The  Government  of  Japan  is  assisting  Pohnpei  State  with  the  installation  of  grid-
connected solar panels on the top of two government buildings. ADB is preparing a proposed 
loan to Yap State to convert part of the diesel-based generation into solar and wind generation. 
These initiatives will contribute an overall average of 15% generation (for the four states) from 
renewable energy.4  
 
8.  Integrating  and  regulating  renewable  energy.  Grid-connected  solar  systems  are 
designed to feed the existing transmission and distribution network. However, contracts need to 
be  developed  to  regulate  the  relationship  between  utilities  and  suppliers.  Pohnpei  State 
promulgated a law that regulates net metering in August 2012. The law was not developed in 
conjunction with the utility, and therefore the ability of the utility to cope with the tariffs and 
charges implied by the law is unclear. Yap State is in the process of drafting net metering 
regulations and has expressed interest in accessing ADB support for this purpose. 
 
9.  Bridging  the  financing  gap  through  private  sector  participation.  Resources  to 
develop renewable energy investment could be funded through tariffs, public debt, or private 
investment. Although tariffs are relatively high in all states compared to international standards, 
they are generally not able to generate sufficient cash flow to cover large investments because 
of high fuel costs. Therefore, Pohnpei State is in the process of procuring 4 megawatt diesel 
generation and 7 megawatt renewable energy generation through private sector participation. 
Pohnpei State’s utility, the Public Utility Corporation issued a request for proposals in June 2012. 
Operation and maintenance are also a challenge, and Yap’s utility, the Yap State Public Service 
Corporation, is considering outsourcing the operation and maintenance of the systems to private 
operators. 
 
10.  The NEP recognizes private sector participation as one of the major drivers for the long- 
term development of renewable energy investment. The current challenge that the four states 
are facing  is  how  to  attract  private  sector  investment to  develop  renewable  generation  at 
reasonable cost. A transparent and enforceable regulatory framework for the energy sector will 
contribute to creating an enabling environment to attract private sector investment.  
 
                                                
4  ADB’s project preparatory TA for the proposed Yap Renewable Energy Development Project estimates that 25% of 
the power generation of Yap State will be sourced from renewable energy once the project is completed.

3 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact will be an improved enabling environment for renewable energy investments 
in the FSM. The outcome will be improved management of renewable energy investments. 
Improved enabling environment consists of improved state laws and regulations and contractual 
arrangements between utilities and power suppliers that promote and facilitate private sector 
investment in renewable energy.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The  outputs  of  the  TA  are  the  (i)  development  of  options  to  improve  the  existing 
regulatory framework (ii) development of options to increase investments in renewable energy 
under new regulatory models, and (iii) design of model contracts for power purchase from 
independent generators. 
 
13.  Output 1: Development of options to improve the regulatory framework. Output 1 
will  recommend  a  regulatory  framework  for  the  power  sector  in  at  least  two  states.  The 
framework will build on the targets and aspirations set out in the NEP. The assessment of 
options will include existing barriers to private sector participation in power generation, and in 
distribution if appropriate. The recommendations will indicate a road map or action plan for at 
least one state to implement the proposed regulatory changes. When needed, assistance will be 
provided to draft laws and regulations. The regulatory aspects that will be considered include (i) 
adequacy of existing laws and regulations to encourage private sector participation in the power 
sector, (ii) net metering and other mechanisms to encourage small-scale on-grid generation, 
and (iii) steps to remove barriers imposed by the existing tariff-setting mechanisms to stimulate 
private investment in the power sector.  
 
14.  Output 1 will assess regulatory aspects that could improve private sector participation. 
When designing options for private sector participation, the study will consider 
(i)  licensing for generation, network, and supply businesses, whether separate for 
each  business,  or  single  licenses  that  separately  define  and  address  each 
business, or separate provisions for each business in a concession contract; 
(ii)  separate audited accounts for generation, network, and supply businesses; 
(iii)  transparent internal contracts for power purchase agreements as the basis on 
which the existing supply business will purchase electricity from each of the 
generating plants of the generation business; and  
(iv)  generation licenses for independent power producers. 
 
15.  Output 2: Development of options for increasing investment in renewable energy. 
Output  2  will  help  the  utilities,  under  the  coordination  and  direction  of  the  Department  of 
Resources and Development, to (i) revise and update investment priorities starting from the 
investments identified in the NEP, (ii) present investment modalities and options, (iii) identify 
resources to pay for investments, and (iv) advise on potential investment proposals. Resources 
to bridge the investment gap might be grants, debt, the utilities’ cash flow generated from tariffs, 
or private capital investment.  
 
16.  As part of output 2, support will be provided to utilities to assess the adequacy of tariffs 
to cover the investment plan in the long run under the four funding options listed. Output 2 will 
also  assess  the  adequacy  of  existing  tariff  setting  methodologies  to  attract  private  sector

4 
 
 
investment, and assist the utilities to develop strengthened tariff methodologies as needed. To 
increase investment in renewable energy, under the assumption that grant financing will not 
always be available, utilities, regulators, and policy makers should develop an understanding on 
how to incorporate tariff components that could cover the investment costs. Output 2 will include 
training on tariff-setting methodologies that would cater to the specific needs of the utilities in the 
FSM.  
 
17.  Output 3: Design of model contracts for independent generation. Output 3 will 
provide assistance to utilities to design model contracts to be employed to purchase power 
generation.  The  model  contracts  should  take  into  account  the  generation  technology 
(conventional  generation  and  renewable  resources)  and  power  producers  (utility  scale  or 
household). Model contracts will be developed for institutional suppliers as well as small-scale 
commercial and household suppliers. A model contract for small-scale, on-grid supply will be 
prepared in the states that have implemented or are drafting regulations that account for net 
metering. Case studies on how other small utilities are regulating net metering will be developed 
and disseminated among the utilities and other stakeholders. Output 3 is expected to provide 
assistance to one or more utilities to design and enter a contract for power supply.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The preliminary cost 
estimates and financing plan are presented in Appendix 2. Proceeds of the TA will be disbursed 
in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
19.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  staff,  domestic 
transportation, office accommodation, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 19 months from 1 February 2013 to 31 August 2014. 
Implementation  arrangements  reflect  the  roles  and  strengths  of  the  national  and  state 
stakeholders. Because of its role as the national policy-making body for the energy sector, the 
Department of Resources and Development will act as  executing agency. The Division of 
Energy under the Department of Resources and Development will supervise the consultants 
hired through the TA and provide counterpart office space during the consultants’ visits to the 
country. 
 
21.  ADB  will  recruit  consulting  firm(s)  to  provide  15  person-months  of  international 
consulting services and 10 person-months of national consulting services. The consultants will 
have regulatory, legal, financial, and engineering expertise. The outline terms of reference for 
the consultants are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be engaged through the quality- and 
cost-based selection method (90:10 quality–cost ratio) in accordance with the Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
22.  Outputs will be monitored throughout the TA duration through review missions and 
quarterly reports and regular communications submitted by the consulting team. The outcome 
will be evaluated upon TA closure and disseminated through a stakeholders’ workshop to be 
held in the FSM.

5 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Federated States of Micronesia for Strengthening the Energy Sector 
Regulatory Framework, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Team Composition and Qualification Requirements for Key Experts 
1.  A firm will be engaged to provide 25 person-months (15 international and 10 national) of 
consulting services. The firm will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The firm will be recruited though a 
quality- and cost-based selection procedure (90:10). A simplified proposal will be used. The 
team will be composed of five team members: four international consultants and one national 
consultant. 
 
2.  Regulatory  expert  and  team  leader  (international,  7  person-months).  The  ideal 
candidate will demonstrate substantial experience in utility regulation, preferably in context of 
small island economies and small grids. The team leader will lead the work of the team in the 
three components, and shall have experience in designing regulatory frameworks as well as 
developing model contracts for private sector participation. 
 
3.  Legal  expert  (international,  1  person-month).  The  ideal  candidate  will  demonstrate 
substantial experience in drafting and enacting legal regulation in the power utilities sector. The 
expert will have experience assessing and reviewing regulation as well as drafting contract 
arrangements for corporatized state-owned enterprises. Familiarity with Pacific legal systems is 
desirable. The lawyer will support the drafting of the regulation and contracts as needed.  
 
4.  Financial  analyst  (international,  4  person-months).  The  financial  analyst  will  have 
proven ability to model the financial performance of power utilities. Familiarity with small utilities, 
poor information systems, and Pacific or small-island contexts is highly desirable. The financial 
analyst will assist the team leader in assessing the cash flow requirement and the resulting 
tariffs under the assumption of implementation of the National Energy Policy. In addition, the 
financial analyst will support the design and administration of the training on tariff review, and 
provide to the participants simple and manageable templates to implement the proposed tariff 
setting methodology. Contribution is expected to all three components. 
 
5.  Power  engineer  (international,  3  person-months).  The  power  engineer  will  have 
substantial  experience  in  designing,  assessing  and/or  rehabilitating  renewable  energy 
generation and distribution systems. The engineer will support the team assessing the utility 
investment  needs  as  well  as  evaluating  proposals  for  renewable  energy  investments  as 
requested by the utility or the state and national government. Contribution is expected to all 
three components.  
 
6.  National  renewable  energy  expert  (national,  10  person-months).  The  national 
renewable energy expert will have demonstrated experience working on technical assistance 
projects for the development of renewable energy in the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM). 
Knowledge of and established relationships with at least one of the power utilities in the FSM 
will be an advantage. Familiarity with the FSM’s National Energy Policy is desirable.  
 
B.  Reporting Requirements and Time Schedule 
7.  The consultants are expected to keep in constant communication with ADB’s project 
officer and the implementing agency. Reports are expected to be submitted in electronic copy 
and addressed to the implementing agency and to ADB’s project officers. At least three paper 
copies of each report are expected to be submitted to the implementing agency, and one paper

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
copy of each report to ADB’s project officers.  
 
8.  The team of experts is expected to deliver the following: 
(i)  Inception report 1 month after contract signing (assumed February 2013). The 
report will follow an inception mission and identify the work plan and the 
assistance to be provided to the national government, state governments, and 
utilities. 
(ii)  Interim report with a review of the power sector and recommendation to foster 
private sector participation by July 2013. The report will include 
(a)  an executive summary with recommendation, 
(b)  the review of relevant policies and regulations for the FSM power sector, 
and 
(c)  case studies to support the recommended changes in regulation. 
(iii)  Tool kit for utilities for contract needs and tariff assessment by December 2013. 
The toolkit will include 
(a)  a summary of the investment gaps identified in two utilities; 
(b)  recommendations on the best strategies to fill the investment gap; and 
(c)  a  model  contract  that  can  be  employed  when  using  private  sector 
participation to bridge the financing gap, presented as case studies from 
other small grids. 
(iv)  Draft final report covering the activities carried out under each component by 
April 2014. The draft final report will include 
(a)  a progress update on regulatory changes, 
(b)  a summary of the investment needs of each utility and options to finance 
the investment plans, including tariff adjustments; and 
(c)  a  regulatory  road  map  for  the  FSM  that  will  be  discussed  during  a 
stakeholders’ workshop. 
(v)  Final report by June 2014. 
 
C.  Counterpart Inputs and Personnel 
9.  The executing agency is the Department of Resources and Development. An officer 
from the department will accompany the team of expert on an inception mission to introduce the 
team to the stakeholders in each state. The team is expected to work with the Department of 
Resources and Development, and in particular under the supervision of the Division of Energy, 
to  develop  a  work  program  that  covers  the  priority  needs  of  at  least  two  states.  The 
government’s staff time and travel budget will be covered by the government’s own budget. 
 
10.  The executing agency will make space available to the consultants, in particular the 
national member of the team, in the office of the Department of Resources and Development. 
Internet connection and local communication expenses through the Department of Resources 
and Development’s facilities will be provided by the executing agency to the consultants free of 
charge.
